title: Picture theatre given the go ahead
text:
Show will finally go on for Avoca cinema redevelopment Richard Noone, Central Coast Gosford Express Advocate March 1, 2017 10:30am 
THE epic 15 year battle to redevelop Avoca Beach Picture Theatre was given the green light yesterday after a court found the iconic building not worthy of a heritage listing and the parking shortfall would only be a problem on Sunday afternoons in summer. 
Land and Environment Court Commissioner Susan O’Neill yesterday upheld an appeal by owners Norman and Beth Hunter to redevelop the site to include a three-level building containing a basement carpark, three additional cinemas, foyer, cafe, amenities and five three-bedroom residential units. 
Central Coast Council initially rejected the development application for the $7.2 million overhaul 
because the proposal would have an adverse impact on the heritage character and qualities of the theatre, provided inadequate on-site car parking and was at odds with coastal protection planning laws. media_camera The proposed redevelopment has been hotly contested for years. Picture: Peter Clark 
Three residents gave evidence during the four-day hearing objecting the proposal, while four gave evidence in support. 
Objectors told the court the proposal was an “over development of the site”, would exacerbate parking problems and impacted the heritage significance of the theatre. 
However, Ms O’Neill found many of the so-called heritage elements of the building, first constructed in 1951, including the parapet, ventilation openings, its “art deco” style doors and the extended awning, timber stair and deck fronting Hunter Park were simply replacements or renovations of what was there originally. media_camera Beth and Norman Hunter have fought to redevelop their cinema since 2002. 
“I accept their agreement that the existing building does not demonstrate aesthetic characteristics worthy of the threshold for a local heritage listing,” she said. 
Ms O’Neill further found while there was a shortfall of 33 parking spaces, they could be “accommodated in the public domain, within the vicinity of the proposal”. 
“There is sufficient parking available in the vicinity of the site to accommodate the demands of a 75 per cent maximum occupancy of the proposal at the peak Sunday summer times during the early afternoon,” she said. 
In approving the development the court ordered the Hunters and the council to negotiate the appropriate opening hours for the cinema, cafe and terrace components within two weeks or return to court. 
Comment is being sought from the Hunters. media_camera Norman Hunter, (second from left, rear) with officials from the Land and Environment Court during the recent assessment of the site and surrounds at Avoca Beach. Picture: Peter Clark
